transcript: â€‰ TW for eating disorders, personal hygiene and depression. So, im 17, a few years back (2022-early 2024) i struggled really badly with my mental health and bodily image, (Im trans MtF) and i ended up developing bulimia and struggled a lot with upkeeping personal hygiene, (just over a year clean from bulimia now and doing a lot better mostly), I got referred for a root canal about 2 years ago and completed it 6 months back, and since i have been taking extra good care of my teeth, (brushing twice sometimes 3 times daily, with colgate and an electric toothbrush, flossing every evening etc) and i have the 6 month checkup in a few days, and i am PETRIFIED. I initially got it done as i had a spot on the gum that kept draining then coming back. I got the root canal, then a crown fitted, and i havent experienced any symptoms (no drainage, no swelling, no new spot, no sensetivity, etc) however during anxiety episodes the last few weeks, ive had a very light dull ache in my mouth, at random spots in my mouth, which goes away when i am not thinking about it. I know its realistically anxiety, and i have had a history of physical anxiety symptoms (Ill hyperfixate on an illness, say a heart attack, and when i worry about it a lot i end up with chest pains etc) , it should be fine the success rates are so high, but the idea of having to have another 2 long appointments terrifies me, i have really bad hypochondria, im scared of needles, i struggle sitting still for long periods. the stress has brought me to a point where i am constantly worrying, its next tuesday the checkup. This is so obviously anxiety part of me thinks, but can someone please just confirm itll be okay? I am so scared its horrible. Any reply is really really appreciated and remove if this isnt okay<33

I got the root canal, then a crown fitted, and i havent experienced any symptoms (no drainage, no swelling, no new spot, no sensetivity, etc) however during anxiety episodes the last few weeks, ive had a very light dull ache in my mouth, at random spots in my mouth, which goes away when i am not thinking about it. I know its realistically anxiety, and i have had a history of physical anxiety symptoms (Ill hyperfixate on an illness, say a heart attack, and when i worry about it a lot i end up with chest pains etc) , it should be fine the success rates are so high, but the idea of having to have another 2 long appointments terrifies me, i have really bad hypochondria, im scared of needles, i struggle sitting still for long periods. the stress has brought me to a point where i am constantly worrying, its next tuesday the checkup. This is so obviously anxiety part of me thinks, but can someone please just confirm itll be okay? I am so scared its horrible. Any reply is really really appreciated and remove if this isnt okay<33

transcript: â€‰ Someone on Reddit said when Amazon has an inventory of something, they don't check the safety/quality of the products. They just dump everything together. So let's say they have 17 Colgate toothpaste tubes and 3 knock offs. They just dump everything together and then ship it out. Even though they have 3 annoyed customers they have 17 happy ones. This model is profitable for them. So you can do your research and make sure it is a reputable brand and still end up with unsafe poorly made products. Also Amazon will make their own products based on what their competitors sell that is successful. For example if they notice lots of people are buying a brand of stainless steel cups they will make their own and market it heavily on their website undercutting the competition. They may even remove the competition from the website. I just don't trust them at all.

transcript: â€‰ Hi everyone. I've seen posts like these in this subreddit and I have noted several ways people have experimented and reduced/reversed cavities. I recently got 6 cavities filled and why they happened in the first place is because of a number of reasons - 1. genetic predisposition 2. continued use of Colgate visible white "enamel safe" toothpaste for a few years 2x a day (I did 2x then to improve my oral health without knowing the abrasive effects of such toothpastes ğŸ¤¦ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸) 3. pitted molars 4. a monthly sick year of 2023 (legit sick every month) could've led to immunity loss and contributed to enamel health because of low iron and b12. Recently, my mental health has turned shit and I feel I betrayed myself by doing pt.2. I am talking to a therapist aboutmy health anxiety but it's honestly pretty bad lol. I cry constantly now and feel catastrophic all the time. This teeth situation is feeding onto my low self esteem and worth. I want to know, is there anyway I can "STRENGTHEN" my teeth naturally, NOT NECESSARILY reverse cavities? I am shit scared of them breaking and falling off etc. and feel addressing this will tremendously help. Some things I've picked up here- 1. nanohydroxyapatit toothpaste (switched to Biomin one in Jan but will switch to this) and especially letting it sit on teeth in trays(?) Can I just spit and let it be? 2. oil pulling 3. K2 tablets? ( I get homeopathic medicine, kinda aversive to allopathy but I'm not sure my doc would rightaway tell me to take these) 4. Low sugar carbs- ironically my teeth were splendid in childhood when I wasn't brushing 2x and had a big sweet tooth but worsened when I reversed the habits lol. maybe my childhood habits caught up?? 5. brushing or rinsing after every meal (making a habit of it now) Is there anything else? I would love your help and find a way to the light

transcript: â€‰ A sense of dÃ©jÃ  vu permeates the latest report on brand trust. Morning Consult's 2025 Most Reputable Brands analysis reveals that the companies consumers rely on most today bear a striking resemblance to those favored during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. This resurgence of trust in established brands underscores a continued prioritization of safety, security, and essential needs, even as the world navigates a new normal. The report, which surveyed consumers across all demographics, highlights a consistent preference for brands associated with cleanliness, health, and reliable service. But what does this sustained loyalty tell us about the evolving consumer mindset and the enduring power of established brands in a rapidly changing world? Across all consumer touchpoints, a handful of categories consistently emerged as leaders in brand trust. These include: Home Keeping and Hygiene: Brands like Dawn, Clorox, Lysol, Mr. Clean, and Home Depot continue to be cornerstones of consumer confidence. Self- and Personal Care: Dove, Oral-B, Kleenex, and Colgate remain trusted staples in daily routines. Health: BAND-AID and Tylenol exemplify the enduring trust in brands providing essential healthcare solutions. Packages and Shipping/Ecommerce: UPS, Amazon, the United States Postal Service, and FedEx are vital for modern commerce and maintain high levels of consumer trust. And, let's not forget the comfort factor: Hershey's and M&M's demonstrate that even indulgence can be a source of reliable satisfaction. Maslow's Hierarchy and the Modern Consumer These favored brands directly address fundamental human needs, as outlined in Maslow's Hierarchy. From physiological needs (food, hygiene) to safety and security, consumers are gravitating towards brands that provide a sense of stability and well-being. This isn't simply nostalgia; it's a reflection of ongoing anxieties and a desire for predictability in an uncertain world. Deeper Dive: Trust Across Specific Verticals Morning Consult's analysis extended beyond broad categories, examining trust within specific consumer verticals. Health Sector Trust Leaders Medicines: Tylenol Health Retail: CVS Health Pharmaceuticals: Bayer Health Services: Minute Clinic at CVS Health Insurance: Blue Cross Blue Shields Personal Care Brand Leaders Personal Care: Dove Dental Care: Oral-B Skin Care: Vaseline Lip Care: ChapStick Beauty: Bath & Body Works Cosmetics: CeraVe Hair Care: Head & Shoulders Gyms: Planet Fitness Hair Services: Great Clips Fitness Equipment: NordicTrack Generational Divides in Brand Loyalty Trust isn't uniform across all age groups. Younger consumers, particularly Millennials and Gen Z, demonstrate a growing trust in social media platforms like TikTok and YouTube, while older generations tend to favor legacy brands with established reputations. This generational gap highlights the evolving role of media and marketing in shaping consumer perceptions. Adweek's analysis provides further insight into these differing perspectives. Pro Tip: Building brand trust requires consistent delivery on promises, transparent communication, and a genuine commitment to customer well-being. The Rise of Health and Sustainability Concerns Recent data from the dunnhumby Consumer Trends Tracker reinforces the growing importance of health and sustainability for U.S. consumers. Two-thirds of consumers prioritize sourcing products that align with their dietary needs, and nearly half believe retailers should actively support healthy choices. This trend extends to a preference for local businesses and products, driven by a desire for transparency and connection. As the 2025 Edelman Trust Barometer demonstrates, trust is increasingly built through local relationships rather than distant national brands. However, economic realities are also impacting consumer behavior. With potential cuts to SNAP benefits and rising food costs, one in four U.S. households, and over a third of those aged 18-34, have been forced to skip meals in the past year. This underscores the critical role of food security and the need for accessible, affordable nutrition. The growing movement towards â€œfood as medicineâ€ is gaining traction, recognizing that food is not merely sustenance but a fundamental component of health and well-being....

transcript: â€‰ The award-winning â€œMagic Duos,â€ out of home campaign reminded people that the combination of their favourite food and an ice-cold Coca-Cola is magic. When CEO Rob GuÃ©nette stood at the helm of a newly merged VML Canada, bringing Taxi and Wunderman Thompson together, he knew the easiest route would be the wrong one. Simply fusing old cultures from the separate firms â€“ Taxi having made its mark with influential creative and Wunderman building its reputation on CRM, commerce, data and tech â€“ wasn't going to be enough. He wanted to build something entirely new: a fresh company that could, from day one, be a serious contender on the national stage. OLG Ontario Racing Unfiltered, a gripping docuseries, brought the raw, behind-the-scenes world of horse racing to life, helping a new audience fall in love with the sport. And in just over a year, with over 500 employees across MontrÃ©al, Toronto and Vancouver offices, the agency has done just that through deliberate leadership choices, an ambitious vision and a culture that prioritizes creativity and connection. â€œWe established the leadership very quickly, so that set the tone,â€ GuÃ©nette says. And then he and Graham Lang, CCO, set one clear goal: â€œWe have to come out of this, not only with a successful merger, but also to land in the top five most creative agencies in Canada with a body of work that represents the totality of our capabilities.â€ Lang highlights that VML Canada ranked fourth in the Strategy 2025 Creative Report Card. The agency now consistently tops creative industry benchmarks. But behind those wins lies a deliberate philosophy that GuÃ©nette and his team installed from the very start: a culture of creativity, connection and integration. At the heart of VML Canada's approach is the philosophy of creating â€œConnected Brandsâ€ â€“ brands that meet customers with the right mix of humanity, persuasion and commerce at every stage of their journey. VML's integrated structure flows across three pillars, with Brand Experience, Customer Experience and Commerce under one roof. The company sees itself as a band of doers, innovators and believers in humanity. And for GuÃ©nette, those words are more than branding â€“ they are the spirit behind every piece of work, whether it's a simple in-store shelf talker or a national television spot, the commitment to high creativity remains the same. â€œPride Unravelled,â€ transformed data into a powerful visual statement and turned complex truths into an unforgettable celebration of identity and impact. VML's geographic reach is key to their success in a multicultural country like Canada. QuÃ©bec isn't an afterthought, for example, it's built into every national campaign from the start. In fact, some national accounts are run entirely out of MontrÃ©al or Vancouver, reflecting the agency's inclusive model. Improv star Pier-Luc Funk electrified the screen in San Ã‰mission, the award-winning comedy special that transformed a TV station's dead airtime into a four-hour overnight hit powered by the all-electric Volkswagen. This approach has paid off, with standout campaigns like Volkswagen's â€œSans Ã‰missionsâ€ emerging from the MontrÃ©al office, which won a Grand Clio for Media. A simple but powerful double entendre, the campaign transformed QuÃ©bec's TV â€œoff-airâ€ screens into a metaphor for Volkswagen's zero-emission vehicles, earning top global recognition and helping the automaker's electrification efforts resonate in a culturally authentic way. Other major accounts like Coca-Cola, Mazda, Fido, OLG, Vancity, Colgate and Kruger have also benefited from VML's distinctly Canadian storytelling. GuÃ©nette also explains that VML Canada negotiated significant local autonomy despite being part of the world's largest agency network, with over 30,000 employees globally. Technological innovation is also playing a part in the agency's future. Through VML's access to WPP Open, a proprietary AI-powered platform, the team can accelerate research and production without sacrificing creative quality. Though AI isn't a replacement for human insight, GuÃ©nette sees it as a powerful enabler. VML helped Coca-Cola Fuze make its Canadian debut with a bold launch campaign and introduced a fresh new brand with a familiar flavour to audiences across the country. Looking ahead, VML Canada's focus is on smart, sustainable growth. With a challenging economic landscape and uncertain global tensions, the agency is doubling down on deepening relationships with existing clients, strengthening their customer experience and commerce capabilities and applying their full creative force across every touchpoint. Ultimately, GuÃ©nette believes the balance between deep national pride and global connectedness is what sets VML Canada apart. That's why VML Canada's mantra is â€œFiercely local. Proudly global.â€ CONTACT: Matt Shoom-Kirsch Chief operating officer matt.shoom-kirsch@vml.com The 2025 A-Listers: Intro Zulu Alpha Kilo: Connecting creativity and impact Mosaic: An era where anything's possible Agnostic: Rewriting narratives in service of the work Weber Shandwick: Where culture, creativity and tech collide Dentsu: Humanity in the age of algorithms Lifelong Crush: Sparking long-term devotion C&B Advertising: Leading with emotion PHD Canada: An intelligent transformation The Hive: Doubling down on beating boring TouchÃ©! : Flexing Canadian media muscle...

transcript: â€‰ Toothbrushes. I've used an expensive Oral-B iO, a cheap Chinese brand from Amazon, and basic non-electric brushes from Crest, Colgate, etc. The expensive Oral-B was disgusting. It had crevices that accumulated mold and slime and were impossible to clean. Lots of people online reported the same issue. It also required expensive brush head replacements every 3 months. I discarded the brush within a year because of the mold and gunk issue. The cheap electric brush had a simple design and thus was easy to clean. The brushing action was rougher compared to the expensive brush, but still good and seemed equally effective. I used it for a few years until it died. The basic brushes are trivial to clean, don't require charging, and cost maybe $10 per year for replacements. They work well enough. I use a one-touch timer on my phone to replicate the electric brushes' built-in timers. And they are easy to travel with since they don't require a charger. I don't miss electric brushes.

transcript: â€‰ NEW YORK (July 9, 2025) â€“â€¯The New York Sirens announced today that defender Allyson Simpson has been re-signed to a two-year Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL) Standard Player Agreement through the 2026-27 season. â€œKnowing that Allyson will be with us for at least the next two seasons adds to this wave of youth,â€ said Sirens General Manager Pascal Daoust. â€œIt's her talent, speed, and leadership that we're proud and excited to build with and around.â€ The 24-year-old from Fort Worth, Texas, was a constant presence on the ice in her rookie season, appearing in all 30 games after being selected by New York in the third round of the 2024 PWHL Draft. She tallied four assists and added one goal, finishing the year with five points which tied for fourth among rookie rearguards. â€œI'm thrilled to be re-signing with the Sirens as we continue to create something special with this organization,â€ said Simpson. â€œI'm excited to play a role in the league's continued growth while helping shape the Sirens into a championship team. I can't wait to get back on the ice with my teammates, old and new, and give everything I have for them and the fans who have supported us from day one.â€ Before turning pro, Simpson honed her skills under Head Coach Greg Fargo at Colgate University, where she played for five seasons. She appeared in 174 games and recorded 107 points, capped by a career-high 34 points (9G, 25A) in 40 games during the 2023-24 campaign. She led the Raiders to a Frozen Four berth after scoring the game-winning goal against Cornell. Internationally, Simpson won back-to-back gold medals with Team USA at the 2017 and 2018 IIHF U18 Women's World Championships. The 5'8â€ Simpson returns to a Sirens lineup that has five other defenders under contract for the 2025-26 season, including Lauren Bernard, Jaime Bourbonnais, Maja NylÃ©n Persson, Jincy Roese and captain Micah Zandee-Hart. Fans looking to stay up to date on ticket release dates, team announcements, and exclusive offers are encouraged to subscribe to The Beat, the official Sirens newsletter. For ticket related inquiries, please contact newyorkinfo@thepwhl.com. Click here for a full list of PWHL offseason transactions. ABOUT NEW YORK SIRENS The New York Sirens is one of eight teams in the newly launched Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL), which was founded in 2023. The PWHL began its inaugural season in January 2024 and features the best women's hockey players in the world. The PWHL has broken multiple attendance records and holds the worldwide record for a women's hockey game. For the latest news and information on the New York Sirens, visitâ€¯newyork.thepwhl.comâ€¯or follow the team onâ€¯Facebook,â€¯Instagram, andâ€¯X.â€¯Follow the league on all social media platforms @thepwhlofficial. ABOUT THE PROFESSIONAL WOMEN'S HOCKEY LEAGUE (PWHL) The Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL) is a professional ice hockey league in North America comprised of eight teams in Boston, Minnesota, MontrÃ©al, New York, Ottawa, Toronto, Seattle and Vancouver, each with rosters featuring the best women's hockey players in the world. Launched on Jan. 1, 2024, the PWHL has broken multiple attendance records and holds the worldwide all-time record for a women's hockey game. In 2024, the PWHL was recognized by Sports Business Journal as the Sports Breakthrough of the Yearâ€¯and received the top position in the first-ever Canadian edition of the Harris Poll, which ranks companies' reputations. transcript: â€‰ Five Below is your one-stop shop for travel size toiletries. Not only do these items fit into even the most compact carry-on, they're all priced low enough to help shoppers save money. For You: 7 Little Luxuries To Buy at Five Below This July GOBankingRates reviewed Five Below's travel care department and pulled our top 12 affordable recommendations for your next flight. Price: $3 Need a sleeve of hand wipes for your trip? Pick up Wet Ones hand wipes for just $3. Each package includes 20 wipes with a wet lock seal to close and retain freshness when not in use. This comes out to paying about 15 cents per wipe. Check Out: 6 Costco Products That Have the Most Customer Complaints View Next: 21 Things To Buy at Dollar Tree This Summer If You Live on Social Security Price: $2 A trio of individually wrapped Kleenex tissues are a must for families on long flights to keep sneezes under control. At $2 per pack, this means Five Below shoppers pay only about 67 cents for each tissue sleeve. Try This: 3 Things Retirees Should Stop Buying To Save Money Amid Tariffs Price: $3 If there's not much space inside your carry-on, consider swapping out a regular-size or electric toothbrush with a folding travel toothbrush instead. These toothbrushes fold up easily to fit in toiletry bags. Hurry though: Just a few colors are still available to shop online. Price: $2 Along with buying a folding toothbrush, it's a good idea to pick up a travel-size Colgate toothpaste. This cheap mini toothpaste is extra handy for carry-on luggage in the event you get food stuck in your teeth during your flight and need to brush before arrival. Price: $2 No matter how long or short your flight is, it's always a good idea to keep a mini deodorant handy to freshen up. Secret deodorant is affordably priced and TSA checkpoint approved at 1.7 ounces. Trending Now: 11 Best New Groceries on Sale at Costco in July Price: $2 For the guys in your traveling party, it never hurts to have Old Spice deodorant handy. At 0.5 ounces, you'll have no trouble slipping one into your carry-on. Price: $2 Heading straight to the hotel after a long day of traveling and don't want to stop at a drugstore to grab toiletries? You're covered with Pantene Pro-V shampoo in a conveniently sized 3.38-ounce tube. Price: $5 What's nice about shopping for Vaseline mini lip tubs is they come in a value pack. Each package includes two mini tubs. Price: $5 Snooze away a long flight in a weighted eye mask. Only pink, green and blue styles are available to shop, so snag one while they're still in stock. Price: $4 You might stand outside for a bit to book rideshares once your flight arrives and, for those moments, you'll be glad you packed a travel size sunscreen. The Sun Bum brand is $4 and features SPF 30 to protect skin from harsh UV rays. Price: $3 Freshen up your face before arriving at your destination with Clarisse makeup remover towelettes. Each sleeve is filled with 30 towelettes designed for all skin types. That's Interesting: I'm a Shopping Expert â€” These 10 Items Are the Best Frugal Buys at Costco Price: $3 Depending where you shop, pill cases and organizers can cost upward of $7. Not at Five Below, where shoppers can pick up a bubble pill case for just $3 apiece. Store all of your prescriptions, vitamins and OTC meds in the pill case's six compartments and save a little extra room in your carry-on that would have otherwise been occupied by bottles and boxes. Editor's note: Prices and availability are accurate as of July 2, 2025, and are subject to change....

SURI toothbrushes are also 25% off on their website as part of the summer sale. Shoppers can read my full review here. transcript: â€‰ Background: I got braces at a very young age, I might have been 9 maybe. I believe I had them for 4 - 5 years. (Got them early bc of a surgery I had.) During this time, I neglected my oral hygiene and that led me to develop many cavities. Maybe around 20, I know, a lot. I ended up getting them filled not too long after. I was still left with weak enamel. Fast forward a few years later, I ended up having to get a gum graft. WORST experience ever. It was awful and I don't want to go through it again. I have tried to do everything. I try to floss daily. Brush 1 - 2 times a day. Enamel toothpaste burns so I just don't use it, I just stick to Colgate because it doesn't burn and seems to help a little bit. I do a water + salt rinse. Once a week I do a water + hydrogen peroxide mix. And on top of that I do oil pulling before I brush every night. I'm about to go to the dentist this week but I wanted opinions and suggestions before hand. I have had multiple dentists and they all said many different things. Some say you can reverse recession, others said I can't. Currently 18, and I'm scared that all of these cavities and neglect from when I was younger are going to lead to root canal's, crowns, more gum grafts, or extraction of the tooth in general. Is there any way I can keep my real teeth throughout the majority of my lifetime even with the current damage at a young age.
